revision.text:
The '''{{IAST|Andhrabhṛtya}}s''' ([[Devanagari]]:आन्ध्रभृत्य) is an Indian dynasty mentioned in the [[Puranas]]. Lists of Andhrabhrtyas have been mentioned in various Puranas. They are mostly identified with [[Satavahana dynasty|Satavahanas]] which replaced the house of the [[Maurya]] in the [[Deccan Plateau|Deccan]] about 230 BC, reigning until the end of 3rd century AD. At the height of its power the dynasty succeeded in extending it reign far to the north, possibly right up to the [[Magadha]].<ref name=NILSA>{{cite book|last1=Shastry|first1=Nilakanta K.A.|title=The Illustrated History of South India: From Prehistoric Times to the Fall of Vijayanagar Oxford India Collection|date=1955|publisher=Oxford University Press|location=Madras|isbn=9780198063568|pages=92}}</ref> The term Andhrabhrtya has been used very ambiguously by some historians, sometimes it is used to mean the Satavahanas and sometimes it is used to mean their [[feudatories]].<ref name=ambi>{{cite book|last1=Sukthankar|first1=Vishnu Sitaram|title=V.S. Sukthankar Memorial Edition, Volume 1|date=1944|publisher=V. S. Sukthankar Memorial Committee, by Karnatak Publishing House|page=257}}</ref> Yet again certain historians claim that the [[Chutus]],who were [[Naga Kingdom|Nagas]], the Younger branch of the Imperial Andhras were called Andhrabhrtya.<ref name=chutu>{{cite book|last1=Indian History Congress|last2=Krishnarao|first2=B.V.|title=Proceedings|date=1938|page=71}}</ref>
The designation ''{{IAST|Andhrajātiya}}'' or ''{{IAST|[[Andhra in Indian epic literature|Andhra]]}}'' is found in the Puranas which represents its founder as {{IAST|Bhṛtya}} or servant of the last {{IAST|[[Kanva dynasty|Kaṇva]]}} king. Sir [[R. G. Bhandarkar]] following the [[Vishnu Purana]] styles the dynasty founded by [[Simuka]] as Andhrabhrtya, i.e. Andhras who were once servants.<ref name=bhand>{{cite book|last1=Raychaudhuri|first1=Hemchandra|title=Political History Of Ancient India|date=2006|publisher=Genesis Publishing Pvt Ltd|isbn=9788130702919|pages=336}}</ref> But that designation is also applied to the seven {{IAST|[[Abhira tribe|Ābhira]]}}s who are mentioned as the successors of the line of the Simuka.<ref name=abhira>{{cite book|last1=Pargiter|first1=F. E.|title=The Purana Text of the Dynasties of the Kali Age|date=2009|publisher=BiblioBazaar|isbn=9781115375603|pages=IV,24, 18}}</ref>
==References== <references />

[[File:Case du pays des bakossis avec les vases et les feux funéraires.jpg|thumb|300px|Bakossi house in 1920]] The '''Bakossi people''' live on the western and eastern slopes of [[Mount Mwanenguba]] and [[Mount Kupe]] in the [[Bakossi Mountains]] of [[Cameroon]]. They number about 200,000, mostly engaged in subsistence farming but also producing some coffee and cocoa.<ref name="Ejedepang-Koge"/>
==Origins==
According to their tradition, the Bakossi are descended from the great hunter Ngoe (or Ngweh) and his beautiful wife Sumediang. They had twelve children. At one time, a supernatural being warned the couple that a flood was coming and told them to make a box in which to escape. They built an ark, taking in their family and all kinds of animals, and survived the flood. The ark came to rest between the twin lakes of Mwanenguba, one of which is said to have a female character and the other male.<ref name=Bime2009/> The different clans claim descent from different children and grandchildren of this couple.<ref name=BACDAhistory/>
The Bakossi are related to other people of the region including the Bafaw, Bakundu, Balong, Bassossi, Mbo, Abo, Miamilo, Baneka, Muaneman, Muange, Bareko, Bakaka, Babong, Balondo, Manehas, Bongkeng, and Bakem.<ref name=BACDAhistory/> The Bakossi people speak a [[Bantu languages|Bantu]] language called [[Akose language|Akose]]. Today, this language includes many loan words from [[English language|English]], [[French language|French]] and word that are also found or related to words in [[Douala language|Douala]].<ref name=BACDAlanguage/> [[Ethnologue]] classifies the language in the Ngoe group of the Lundu-Balong family.<ref name=Ethnologue/>
==Environment== [[File:PhotoBrumes18.jpg|thumb|300px|Photograph taken while shooting the 2007 documentary "Les Brumes du Manengouba" in the Bakossi Forests]] The land occupied by the Bakossi people includes both highlands and lowlands. It has fertile soils, watered by streams that rise in the mountains, and is covered by dense forest which contain a wide variety of trees, birds and animals.<ref name="Ejedepang-Koge"/> Many of the Bakossi grow coco yam, cassava and some corn for food. For cash they cultivate coffee in the higher parts and cocoa lower down.<ref name=Minzner/> More exotic foods include tadpoles and males of the [[Hairy Frog]], which are thought to fall from the sky and, when eaten, to help childless human couples become fertile.<ref name=Gonwouo/> Among the Bakossi, a hunter is respected for his skills and achievements as much as for the economic value of the animals he has managed to kill.<ref name=Cowlishaw2000/>
The [[Bakossi Forest Reserve]] of {{convert|5,517|km2|sqmi}} was created in 1956. In 2000, the main section of Bakossi was designated a protected forest. All logging was banned and Kupe became a "strict nature reserve". The local Bakossi people participated in delineating the boundaries.<ref name=Lambi2009/> There were large gains in management effectiveness of the forest between 2003 and 2007 although the local people are still not well integrated into management of the area and there are weaknesses in education on environmental subjects.<ref name=Topa2009/>
==Traditional beliefs== {{Further information|Nyongo society}} The Bakossi beliefs and customs included belief and participation in [[juju]]s, a rather vague concept where the name of a juju might apply to a secret society, objects such as masks associated with the society, and certain magical powers. ''Mwakum'' was the most powerful of all the jujus, invisible, mysterious and full of magic. Some jujus were restricted to men of a certain age and demanded an initiation fee. Jujus and their ceremonies kept peace in the villages, warded off evils and detected the presence of witches.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=QSmW1QNU6UoC&pg=PA7 |page=7ff |title=Jujus in the Forest Area of West Cameroon |editor=Peter Valentin |publisher=Basler Afrika Bibliographien |year=1980 |location=Basel}}</ref>
The Bakossi people attached sinister magical properties to Mount Kupe. They believed that ''Nyongo'', or members of the ''ekom'' association of witches, could put people to work on invisible plantations on the mountain. While still living, the future slaves would be given to a witch by a greedy relative in return for joining the association and gaining a plantation. After they appeared to die, but in fact became ''ekongi'', the relatives were stolen from their graves by the witches and sold to a plantation owner.<ref name=Clough2001/> The practice of visiting a trader in ekongi is reported from 1962 in [[Douala]], the commercial capital of Cameroon. The "ekongeur" would throw his visitor into a deep sleep through hypnosis. He would see the plantations with the ekongi working, and would be offered a plantation in return for someone such as his mother. On waking up, the ekongeur would explain that he now should take his time to decide what he would do...<ref name=Grinker1997/> There may be an echo in this belief of early experiences with the slave trade.<ref name=Clough2001/>
The ''Nyongo'' could also find closed bundles on the mountain which might contain either riches or misfortunes, including illness and death. The bundle had to be brought back unopened and immediately thrown in the river if it was found to contain bad luck.<ref name=Clough2001/> By the 1950s a belief had risen that anyone who could afford a modern house with a tin roof must be a ''Nyongo'', earning his wealth from the labors of his dead relatives. There was a reluctance to build such a house, even if the owner visibly did the work with his own hands and none of his relatives died. When a witch died, he could also become an ''ekongi''. To prevent this, he might be buried face down so he could not rise, perhaps with his head severed from his body.<ref name=Douglas2004/> These beliefs are now discredited. Heinrich Balz, in his 1984 study of the Bokassi, ''Where the Faith Has to Live'', reported that before dying the last ''Ekom'' men left a message that there was no longer anything good to be found on Koupe. To get wealthy the people should take their cutlasses and open farms in the bush.<ref name=Isichei2004/>
The Bakossi observed a ten-day cycle rather than the seven-day week common elsewhere. As elsewhere, they did not align their weeks with months.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2ZMOAAAAQAAJ&pg=PA251 |page=251 |title=Babungo |author=Willi Schaub |publisher=Taylor & Francis |year=1985 |ISBN=0-7099-3352-5}}</ref>
==Pre-independence history== [[File:Bundesarchiv Bild 163-051, Kamerun, Weihnachten am Mungo.jpg|thumb|300px|Two white settlers and local children and men on the [[Mungo River, Cameroon|Mungo River]], Christmas 1901]] The different Bakossi tribes originally each occupied independent territories, living as hunter-gatherers.<ref name=BACDAhistory/> As the [[Atlantic slave trade]] developed, the coastal town of [[Douala]] became an important trading center, reaching into the interior Bakossi Mountains along the [[Mungo River, Cameroon|Mungo valley]]. However, by the 1840s the slave trade had been replaced by the palm oil trade. Little is known about the effect on the Bakossi of either trade, but they were certainly involved in both. In nearby regions, slaves were still used domestically on palm oil plantations as gatherers, processors and carriers long after the export of slaves to the USA, Caribbean and Brazil had ceased.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=2b9iucQcDRcC&pg=PA150 |page=150 |title=The pre-colonial period: Volume 1 of An economic history of tropical Africa |editor=Z.A. Konczacki |editor2=J.M. Konczacki |publisher=Routledge |year=1977 |ISBN=0-7146-2919-7}}</ref>
During the European colonial era, the Bakossi came under German rule in the 1880s, and then, after [[World War I]], their land was split between British and French colonies.<ref name=BACDAhistory/> The Mungo River, which flows through Bakossi territory, was taken as the southern boundary between the two colonies. Starting in the first half of the 20th century, [[Bamileke people]] began to migrate into Bakossi territory, particularly to the [[Tombel]] area, where they found work on the plantations and escaped the harsh forced-labor conditions on the French side of the border. They were welcomed by the Bakossi, who gave them land in return for free labor.<ref name=Konings2009/> The use of laborers in this way was consistent with the Bakossi's memories of employing slave labor and their belief in the invisible slave plantations on Mount Kupe.<ref name=Geschiere1997/>
In 1953, the Kumba Eastern Area Federation was established as an indigenous authority covering all the Bakossi.<ref name=BACDAhistory/> In the period immediately following [[World War II]], the Bakossi people enjoyed a period of prosperity. Cocoa prices were high, and the farmers did not have to work since they could employ a sharecropper to tend the crop in return for one-third of the earnings. With nothing else to spend their money on, the men would buy cases of Spanish gin and brandy, consuming the booze in long drinking bouts that lasted all night. By the 1960s, the hangover set in as the people started to realize the need to invest in more important things, particularly education and became aware that they may have lost control of their land.<ref name=Geschiere1997/>
==Post-independence troubles== [[File:Mungo valley, Cameroon.svg|thumb|300px|Mungo River valley. The river and then the mountain line formed the boundary between the former British and French colonies.]] The modern independent state of Cameroon was formed in 1961 when the southern part of the [[British Cameroons]] united with the [[Republic of Cameroon]], which had succeeded the French colony of [[Cameroun]] in 1960.<ref name=Anyangwe2008/> The Bakossi were opposed to the union, and the Mwane-Ngoe Union of the Bakossi asked the [[United Nations]] to respect their wish to avoid the conflict in Cameroun and instead let them join [[Nigeria]].<ref name="Chem-Langhëë 2004"/> At first the Southern Cameroons retained a degree of independence in a federation between two states.<ref name=Percival2008/> Full unification was resisted by the people of Southern Cameroons since they had a more democratic society than prevailed in the rest of the country under the oppressive regime of [[Ahmadou Ahidjo]].<ref name=Anyangwe2008/> In 1963, the Bangem District was created covering the land occupied by the Bakossi.<ref name=BACDAhistory/>
In the late 1950s and early 1960s, tensions began to rise between the Bakossi and the Bamileke people, who were becoming increasingly successful as farmers. The [[Union of the Peoples of Cameroon|UPC]] rebellion broke out in the French territory in 1955, with Bamilekes prominent among the rebels. A growing number of Bamileke fled from persecution in the east and settled with their kin in Bakossi country. After unification in 1961 the UPC rebels came under increasing pressure and their numbers shrank. The remainder turned to living off the land, demanding supplies from the villages and capturing youths whom they inducted into their forces.<ref name=Konings2009/>
By late 1966, medicine men were active in distributing secret medicines which would give the Bakossi men courage and make them immune to bullets or machete strokes. After three Bakossi were killed by unknown assailants on 31 December 1966, the Bakossi went on a rampage, killing 236 Bamileke settlers, looting and burning their houses. In response the army moved in, rounded up all able-bodied Bakossi men in the Tombel area, and placed them in detention camps. Many were severely tortured to obtain confessions. Eventually 143 Bakossi men were put on trial and 17 sentenced to death. 75 received life sentences of life imprisonment.<ref name=Konings2009/> Bangem District was split into Northern and Southern districts in 1968, and, in 1977, the Bakossi Council was also split into Northern and Southern councils.<ref name=BACDAhistory/>
==Economic difficulties==
Cameroon is a poor country, with a 2010 GPD per capita of US$2,300, placing it 183 among countries by wealth. Most of the people are engaged in agriculture.<ref name="CIA Cameroon">{{cite web |url=https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/geos/cm.html |title=Africa::Cameroon |publisher=CIA |accessdate=2011-02-10}}</ref> After independence the government faced growing demand for rural water supply. The government required that local communities provide labor to build the water facilities between 1964 and 1988, providing water through public taps. However, local councils found that the cost of supplying water to these taps was eating up a large part of their budget. When they failed to pay their bills the National Water Supply Company of Cameroun (SNEC) simply disconnected the supply. Starting in 1993 the SNEC tried privatizing the taps to reduce waste and recover costs, with an individual running the tap and selling the water. The Bakossi women of Tombel made a dramatic protest against these changes. In April 1994, 4,000 women marched on the SNEC offices, led by some old women who marched naked - their final weapon before death - and urinated on the steps. Herbs were thrown on the steps, which were said to be able to turn into poisonous snakes if anyone crossed the threshold. The SNEC employees had fled and refused to return from fear of the people and of the juju the women had placed. The outcome was partial success. Control of the water supply was given to a committee headed by the woman who had organized the protest. But the supply remained uncertain.<ref name=Coles2005/>
[[File:Ngab farming trainees.png|thumb|300px|Farming trainees at [[Ngab]] in 2008]] As of 2008, young Bakossi farmers faced the difficult choice of trying to make their way in the city or taking their chances in rural development. Some had started growing oil palms in [[Mbulle]] but lacked a processing machine, fertilizers and chemicals. Most important they lacked roads and transport to get their crops to market. Earlier cooperatives that gave some collective bargaining power had been disbanded leaving cash crop farmers at the mercy of private buyers.<ref>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=fRIts0AZKT4C&pg=PA149 |page=149 |title=Interdisziplinare Afrikaforschung und neuer Afropessimismus. Symposion zum 70. Geburtstag von Heinrich Balz |author=Jürgen Thiesbonenkamp |author2=Andreas-Martin Selignow (Hg.) |publisher=Andreas-Martin Selignow |ISBN=3-933889-13-8}}</ref>
==Prominent people==
[[Albert Ngome Kome]] was a leading political figure of the Bakossi people.<ref name=Olson1996/> He was Minister of Transport from 8 November 1979 to 17 July 1984 under the governments of Ahmadou Ahidjo and his successor [[Paul Biya]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cncc-cam.org/pdf/annuaire_cncc/a_m_09_ang.pdf |title=Cameroon National Shippers’ Council |publisher=Cameroon National Shippers’ Council |accessdate=2011-02-11 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110725183002/http://www.cncc-cam.org/pdf/annuaire_cncc/a_m_09_ang.pdf |archivedate=2011-07-25 |df= }}</ref> A 2006 article described Kome as a member of the Kupe Muanenguba elite, which also included Mr Ekinde Sone Bernard Ivo an educationist and politician, Professor [[Elvis Ngolle Ngolle]], appointed Minister of Forests and Wildlife on 22 September 2006, Chief Justice [[Epuli Aloh Mathias]],<ref>https://www.cameroon-tribune.cm/articles/9203/fr/</ref> Professor [[Charles Epie Alobwede]], Professor [[Paul Ndue]],Thomas Kolle Ekaney, Late Chief Lucas Nzuonkwelle, Ambassador Nkwelle Ekaney, Mr. Ngole Philip Ngwese, Makoge Ivo Charles, Nhon Mesue Stephen Nzuonkwelle, Nhon Nzuonkwelle Emmanuel Nkwelle, CD Ewu Ngeme David, Chief Ewange of Babubock, Mme Ngumbah née Mesue Juliana Mbende, Nicolas Nkwelle Metuge, Nhon Nkwelle Jude Nzuonkwelle,General Ekongwese Divine Nnoko appointed Military General on a presidential decree of June 29, 2017, [[Paul Elung]] chief Alex Ngome Ntoko, Chief Nhon Nzoh Ngandembou, Hon. John Ebong Ngole, Dr.Nkwelle Akede Aaron, a Pediatrician at SONARA Clinic ManassehBobga and Late Justice Ngalame Kome (Supreme Court Justice and one time secretary of state) .<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.postnewsline.com/2006/09/kupe_muanenguba_2.html |date= 28 September 2006 |title=Kupe Muanenguba Exhorted To Support Ngolle Ngolle |author=Joe Dinga Pefok |publisher=Up Station Mountain Club |accessdate=2011-02-11}}</ref>

Mitchell |publisher=Berghahn Books |year=2001 |ISBN=1-57181-992-4}}</ref> <ref name=Coles2005>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=AOSycAr4NUgC&pg=PA68 |page=68 |title=Gender, water and development |author1=Anne Coles |author2=Tina Wallace |publisher=Berg Publishers |year=2005 |ISBN=1-84520-125-6}}</ref> <ref name=Cowlishaw2000>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=tbT7LYnV6AcC&pg=PA401 |page=401 |title=Primate conservation biology |author1=Guy Cowlishaw |author2=Robin Ian MacDonald Dunbar |publisher=University of Chicago Press |year=2000 |ISBN=0-226-11636-0}}</ref> <ref name=Douglas2004>{{cite book |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=FG0ds-lZ9gkC&pg=PA147 |page=147ff |title=Witchcraft Confessions and Accusations |author=Mary Douglas |publisher=Routledge |year=2004 |ISBN=0-415-33070-X}}</ref> <ref name="Ejedepang-Koge">{{cite web |url=http://allbakossiconference.yolasite.com/about-us.php |title=BAKOSSI: INFORMATION NOTE |author=S. Gonwouo |author2=Mark-Oliver Rödel |lastauthoramp=yes |journal=SALAMANDRA |volume=44 1 |pages=23–34 |date=20 February 2008 |ISSN=0036-3375}}</ref> <ref name=Grinker1997>{{cite book {{infobox ethnic group |group = Bolivians in Brazil |image = |caption = Notable Bolivians in Brazil: |population = '''about 100,000'''[http://www.memorialdoimigrante.sp.gov.br/historico/e4.htm Estatísticas gerais: imigrantes e descendentes] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070613000000/http://www.memorialdoimigrante.sp.gov.br/historico/e4.htm |date=June 13, 2007 }} |popplace= [[Brazil]]: Mainly [[Southeastern Brazil]]
[[Center-West Region, Brazil|Center-Western]] Brazil {{·}} border regions and some metropolises along [[North Region, Brazil|Northern Brazil]] |langs= [[Spanish language|Spanish]] {{·}} [[Brazilian Portuguese|Portuguese]]
Minority: [[Guaraní language|Guaraní]] {{·}} [[Aymará language|Aymará]] {{·}} possibly other Amerindian languages as [[Quechua language|Quechua]] |rels= Mostly [[Roman Catholic Church|Roman Catholicism]]
[Folk religion]]s. |related= [[Demographics of Bolivia|Bolivians]]
other [[Brazilian people|Brazilian]], [[Hispanic]] and [[Hispanophone]] people }} '''Bolivians in Brazil''' are individuals of full, partial, or predominantly [[Bolivia|Bolivian]] ancestry, or a Bolivian-born person residing in [[Brazil]]. The governments of Bolivia and Brazil have begun to develop an agreement to regularize the situation of several thousand undocumented Bolivian immigrants in Brazil. [http://www.elreloj.com/article.php?id=18609 El Reloj.(Spanish)] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20101202223140/http://www.elreloj.com/article.php?id=18609 |date=December 2, 2010 }} According to estimates by the Ministry's of Latin American immigrants and the National Association of Immigrants from Brazil more than 200,000 Bolivians are working illegally in [[São Paulo]].[http://www.etni-cidade.net/bolivianos_saude.htm ''Bolivianos são o grupo mais atingido pela tuberculose em São Paulo''.Agência Brasil. (Portuguese)] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090830072536/http://www.etni-cidade.net/bolivianos_saude.htm |date=2009-08-30 }}[http://www.generaccion.com/usuarios/actualidad/articulos/?codarticulocliente=304 ''Mas de 200.00 Bolivianos trabajan en Sao Paulo'' (Spanish).] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081206132110/http://www.generaccion.com/usuarios/actualidad/articulos/?codarticulocliente=304 |date=December 6, 2008 }} Bolivians living in Brazil are the fifth largest immigrant group, behind only of the Americans, Japanese, Paraguayans, and the Portuguese.http://noticias.terra.com.br/brasil/numero-de-imigrantes-no-brasil-cresceu-63-em-10-anos-diz-ibge,235873f2ef6da310VgnCLD200000bbcceb0aRCRD.htmlhttp://noticias.uol.com.br/cotidiano/ultimas-noticias/2012/04/27/numero-de-imigrantes-morando-no-brasil-quase-dobra-em-dez-anos-sp-e-pr-sao-os-principais-destinos.htm ==Notable Bolivian Brazilians== *[[German Efromovich]] *[[Edivaldo Hermoza]] *[[Marcelo Moreno Martins|Marcelo Moreno]] *[[Miguel Krigsner]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Bolivian diaspora}} {{Ancestry and ethnicity in Brazil}} {{Brazil topics}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Bolivians In Brazil}} [[Category:Bolivian emigrants to Brazil|*]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Brazil]] [[Category:Brazilian people of Bolivian descent| ]] [[Category:Bolivian diaspora|Brazil]] {{Brazil-ethno-group-stub}}

revision.text:
{{Use Australian English|date=October 2016}} {{Use dmy dates|date=October 2016}} '''Cape Wickham Links''' is an 18-hole golf course that was constructed on the northern tip of [[King Island (Tasmania)|King Island]], {{convert|48|km}} north of [[Currie, Tasmania|Currie]], on [[Tasmania]].<ref name=james14>{{cite web | url=http://www.golfaustralia.com.au/news/king-island-golfs-next-mecca-427645 | title= King Island: Golf's Next Mecca | author= James, Brendan | date= 17 December 2014 | accessdate=3 October 2016 | work=Golf Australia}}</ref> It opened to the public on 30 October 2015. A par 72 course, it is {{convert|6150|m|yard|0|abbr=off}} long.<ref name=rv>{{cite web | url=http://www.ausgolf.com.au/guide/club/CapeWickhamLinks/review | title=Course Review: Cape Wickham Links | work=ausgolf: Australia's most informative golf website |author1=Berg, Selwyn |author2=Kennedy, Garry | accessdate=3 October 2016 | date=2015}}</ref> Critically acclaimed, it has been ranked third in the Australian ''[[Golf Digest]]'' Top 100 Courses rankings,<ref>{{ cite news | author= Tucker, Jim | url=http://www.couriermail.com.au/sport/golf/cape-wickham-golf-course-on-king-island-is-worth-travelling-for/news-story/069b40ade6810ccce6f94bba1c8d48c2 | work=Courier-Mail | title=Cape Wickham golf course on King Island is worth travelling for | date=18 February 2016 | accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref> and 24th in the world.<ref name=oz>{{ cite news | author=Neales, Sue | url= http://www.theaustralian.com.au/life/travel/golf-gives-new-reason-to-seek-out-remote-king-island/news-story/7ac7193abe7954b03defc31e36894eef | date=23 January 2016 | title=Golf gives new reason to seek out remote King Island |work=[[The Australian]] | accessdate=3 October 2016 |subscription=y}}</ref><ref name="GD201617">{{cite web|url=http://www.golfdigest.com/story/worlds-100-greatest-golf-courses-2016-ranking|title=World's 100 Greatest Golf Courses (2016–17 Ranking)|last=Whitten|first=Ron |work=Golf Digest|publisher=Condé Nast|accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref>
==History== Andrew Purchase bought the land in 2011. Extra land was required, which resulted in Victorian course owner Duncan Andrews investing in the project,<ref name=james14/> and the Tasmanian Government making some public land available for lease.<ref name=oz/> Golf course designer Mike De Vries designed the course, nine holes of which straddle the coastline. The windy climate necessitated the use of multiple types of fescue grasses for the greens.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2015-11-02/golf-courses-expected-to-drive-tourism-growth-for-king-island/6903238|title=Two new golf courses expected to drive tourism growth for King Island|last=Hunt|first=Linda |date=2 November 2015|work=ABC News|accessdate=3 October 2016}}</ref> The course has cost $8 million to buy and construct.<ref name=oz/> Covering around 120 hectares (300 acres), the course encroached on the nesting burrows of [[short-tailed shearwater]]s. Some of these were destroyed in the course's creation, however, the construction took place outside the breeding season while the birds were absent. The site owners reported that the birds dug new burrows in natural areas the next season, and that the course has prevented access to locals taking birds for food.<ref>{{cite journal|last=Oliver|first=Darius|date=March–April 2015|title=Cape Wickham Wonder|journal=Australian Turfgrass Management|volume=17|issue=2|pages=6–10|url=https://www.agcsa.com.au/sites/default/files/uploaded-content/website-content/cape_wickham_17.2_pg_6-10pdf.pdf}}</ref>
The course has been designed with wide fairways to accommodate for the strong westerly winds known as the [[Roaring Forties]].<ref name=james14/> Holes singled out for praise by ausgolf reviewer Gary Kennedy include the par five 9th hole, complete with ravine, the par three 11th hole alongside a rocky cove, and the picturesque 18th hole.<ref name=rv/> Some concerns have been raised over the loss of access to public land, as the beach locale Victoria Cove was incorporated into the 18th hole and blocked from public use.<ref name=oz/>
==References== {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Golf clubs and courses in Tasmania]] [[Category:Clubs and societies in Australia]] [[Category:2015 establishments in Australia]] [[Category:King Island (Tasmania)]]

{{multiple issues| {{COI|date=July 2011}} {{Refimprove|date=July 2011}} }} [[Image:Challenger final logo 250px.png|right|thumb|Logo]] '''Challenger Center for Space Science Education''' is a [[United States]] 501(c)(3) [[non-profit organization]] headquartered in [[Washington, DC]]. It was founded in 1986 by the families of the astronauts who died in the [[Space Shuttle Challenger disaster|Space Shuttle ''Challenger'' disaster]] on January 28, 1986. The organization offers dynamic, hands-on exploration and discovery opportunities to students around the world. These programs equip students with the knowledge, confidence, and skills that will help better our national social and economic well-being. Challenger Learning Centers give students the chance to become astronauts and engineers and solve real-world problems as they share the thrill of discovery on missions through the Solar System. Using space simulation and role-playing strategies, students bring their classroom studies to life and cultivate the skills needed for future success. == United States == {| class="wikitable sortable" style="width:98%" !scope="col" |Center Name !scope="col" |Location !scope="col" |Website |- |Challenger Learning Center of Alaska||Kenai, Alaska|| |- |Challenger Space Center of Arizona||Peoria, Arizona|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at the [[Columbia Memorial Space Center]] ||Downey, California|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at Chabot Space and Science Center ||Oakland, California|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at the Discovery Museum Science & Space Center ||Sacramento, California|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Colorado at the Colorado Consortium for Earth & Space Science Education ||Colorado Springs, Colorado|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at the Discovery Museum ||Bridgeport, Connecticut|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at Kirby Smith Middle School ||Jacksonville, Florida|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Tallahassee ||Tallahassee, Florida|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at the Coca-Cola Space Science Center ||Columbus, Georgia|| |- |Challenger Center Hawaii at Barbers Point Elementary School ||Kapolei, Hawaii|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at Heartland Community College ||Normal, Illinois|| |- |Challenger Learning Center for Science & Technology ||Woodstock, Illinois|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Northwest Indiana ||Hammond, Indiana|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Kentucky ||Hazard, Kentucky|| |- |Challenger Learning Center - Louisville, Academy @ Shawnee ||Louisville, Kentucky|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at Paducah, West Kentucky Community and Technical College ||Paducah, Kentucky|| |- |Challenge Learning Center of Maine ||Bangor, Maine|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at Howard B. Owens Science Center ||Lanham, Maryland|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at the Christa Corrigan McAuliffe Center, Framingham State University ||Framingham, Massachusetts|| |- |Challenger Learning Center – St. Louis ||St. Louis, Missouri|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Northern Nevada ||Sparks, Nevada|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Las Cruces ||Las Cruces, New Mexico|| |- |Buehler Challenger & Science Center ||Paramus, New Jersey|| |- |Town of Ramapo Challenger Learning Center ||Airmont, New York|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of the Twin Tier Region ||Allegany, New York|| |- |New York City Center for Space Science Education ||New York City, New York|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Greater Rochester ||Rochester, New York|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of the Greater Capital Region at miSci ||Schenectady, New York|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Dayton ||Dayton, Ohio|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Lake Erie West ||Oregon, Ohio|| |- |Challenger Learning Center of Richland County School District One ||Columbia, South Carolina|| |- |Challenger STEM Learning Center; University of Tennessee Chattanooga ||Chattanooga, Tennessee|| |- |Texas State Technical College Challenger Learning Center ||Harlingen, Texas|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at the George Observatory ||Needville, Texas|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at the Scobee Education Center, San Antonio College ||San Antonio, Texas|| |- |Challenger Learning Center Richmond at the MathScience Innovation Center ||Richmond, Virginia|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at the Museum of Flight||Seattle, Washington|| |- |Challenger Learning Center at Wheeling Jesuit University||Wheeling, West Virginia|| |- |} == International == Challenger Learning Center at the Ontario Science Center (Toronto, Canada)

http://www.challenger.org/where-we-are/ == Advisor Council == Notable members of the advisor council have included: *President [[George H.W. Bush]] *Senator and astronaut [[John Glenn]] ==Board of directors== Notable members of the Board of Directors include: *Charles Resnik MD - Brother of [[Judith Resnik]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.challenger.org Official Website] *[http://www.challenger.org/where-we-are Teacher Resources] *[https://www.youtube.com/ccsse Challenger Center Youtube Channel] {{STS-51L}} [[Category:Space Shuttle program]] [[Category:Science education]] [[Category:NASA Museum Alliance]]

'''Cybersex''', also called '''computer sex''', '''Internet sex''', '''netsex''' and, colloquially, '''cyber''' or '''cybering''', is a [[virtual sex]] encounter in which two or more people connected remotely via [[computer network]] send each other [[sexually explicit]] messages describing a sexual experience. In one form, this fantasy sex is accomplished by the participants describing their actions and responding to their chat partners in a mostly written form designed to [[Sexual arousal|stimulate]] their own sexual feelings and fantasies.<ref name="hahnstruct">{{Cite book | last = Hahn | first = Harley | title = The Internet Complete Reference | edition = 2nd | publisher = Osborne McGraw-Hill | year = 1996 | isbn = 0-07-882138-X | page = 570 | quote = The goal of mud sex is the same as the goal of regular sex (without the babies): to bond temporarily in a way that is physically and emotionally satisfying. To do so, two people will exchange messages so as to lead one another into a high level of sexual arousal, culminating in a well-defined resolution. }}</ref> Cybersex often includes [[real life]] [[masturbation]].<ref name="hahnmast">{{Cite book | last = Hahn | first = Harley | title = The Internet Complete Reference | edition = 2nd | publisher = Osborne McGraw-Hill | year = 1996 | isbn = 0-07-882138-X | page = 570 | quote = To be blunt, most mud sex is also accompanied by the people sexually gratifying themselves in real life at the same time. }}</ref> Environments in which cybersex takes place are not necessarily exclusively devoted to that subject, and participants in any Internet chat may suddenly receive a message of invitation). The quality of a cybersex encounter typically depends upon the participants' abilities to evoke a vivid, visceral mental picture in the minds of their partners. Imagination and [[suspension of disbelief]] are also critically important. Cybersex can occur either within the context of existing or intimate relationships, e.g. among lovers who are geographically separated, or among individuals who have no prior knowledge of one another and meet in virtual spaces or cyberspaces and may even remain anonymous to one another. In some contexts cybersex is enhanced by the use of a [[webcam]] to transmit real-time video of the partners.
==Environments==
Cybersex is commonly performed in [[Internet]] [[chat room]]s (such as [[IRC]], [[talker]]s or web chats) and on [[instant messaging]] systems. It can also be performed using webcams, voice chat systems like Skype, or online games and/or virtual worlds like ''[[Second Life]]''. The exact definition of cybersex—specifically, whether real-life masturbation must be taking place for the online sex act to count as cybersex—is up for debate.<ref name="whatiscybersex">{{cite web| last = Ruberg | first = Bonnie | url = http://www.villagevoice.com/2007-05-15/columns/what-counts-as-cybersex/ | title = What Counts as Cybersex? | work = The Village Voice | date = 2007-05-18 | accessdate = 2010-04-20 }}</ref> It is also fairly frequent in [[online role-playing game]]s, such as [[MUD]]s and [[MMORPG]]s, though approval of this activity varies greatly from game to game. Some online social games like ''[[Red Light Center]]'' are dedicated to cybersex and other adult behaviors. These online games are often called [[AMMORPG]]s.
Cybersex may also be accomplished through the use of [[Avatar (computing)|avatars]] in a multiuser software environment. It is often called '''mudsex''' or '''netsex''' in MUDs. In [[TinyMUD]] variants, particularly [[TinyMUCK|MUCKs]], the term '''TinySex''' ('''TS''') is very common.<ref name="hahnmud">{{Cite book | last = Hahn | first = Harley | title = The Internet Complete Reference | edition = 2nd | publisher = Osborne McGraw-Hill | year = 1996 | isbn = 0-07-882138-X | page = 570 | quote = MUD SEX refers to the acting out of erotic feelings by two people while typing a series of sexually explicit messages. (Mud sex is also referred to as NET SEX or—on a TinyMud—TINYSEX.) }}</ref><ref name="busey">{{Cite book | last = Busey | first = Andrew | title = Secrets of the MUD Wizards | publisher = [[SAMS Publishing]] | year = 1995 | isbn = 0-672-30723-5 | page = 95 | quote = MUD sex is another MUD item that may seem a bit shocking to some. MUD sex (sometimes called TinySex—usually on TinyMUDs, MUCKs, and MUSHes) is a lot like phone sex. As you know, most MUDs have a high degree of flexibility when it comes to expressing oneself and communicating—and if you're a little creative, you can use these commands (such as '''say''' and '''emote''' discussed in Chapter 5) to have MUD sex (or TinySex, depending on the type of MUD it is). }}</ref>
Though text-based cybersex has been in practice for decades,<ref>{{Cite book | last = Dibbell | first = Julian | authorlink = Julian Dibbell | url = http://www.juliandibbell.com/mytinylife | title = My Tiny Life | publisher = Henry Holt | year = 1998 | isbn = 0-8050-3626-1 | accessdate = 2010-04-20 }}</ref> the increased popularity of [[webcam]]s has raised the number of online partners using two-way video connections to "expose" themselves to each other online—giving the act of cybersex a more visual aspect. There are a number of popular, commercials [https://stripcamfun.com/blog/this-is-a-place-to-have-cybersex-at/ webcam sites] that allow people to openly masturbate on camera while others watch them.<ref name="liketowatch">{{cite web | last = Ruberg | first = Bonnie | url = http://www.villagevoice.com/2007-07-24/columns/do-you-like-to-watch/ | title = Do You Like to Watch? | work = The Village Voice | date = 2007-07-27 | accessdate = 2010-04-20 }}</ref> Using similar sites, couples can also perform on camera for the enjoyment of others.
In online worlds like ''Second Life'' and via webcam-focused chat services, however, Internet sex workers engage in cybersex in exchange for both virtual and real-life currency.<ref name="upskirt">{{cite web | last = Ruberg | first = Bonnie | url = http://www.villagevoice.com/2007-08-28/columns/peeking-up-the-skirt-of-online-sex-work/ | title = Peeking Up the Skirt of Online Sex Work | work = The Village Voice | date = 2007-08-31 | accessdate = 2010-04-20 }}</ref>
==Advantages== Cybersex provides various advantages: * Cybersex allows real-life partners who are physically separated to continue to be sexually intimate. In geographically separated relationships, it can function to sustain the sexual dimension of a relationship in which the partners see each other only infrequently face to face. Also, it can allow partners to work out problems that they have in their sex life that they feel uncomfortable bringing up otherwise.<ref name="autogenerated1">Grov, Christian, Brian Joseph Gillespie, Tracy Royce, and Janet Lever. 2011. “Perceived Consequences of Casual Online Sexual Activities on Heterosexual Relationships: A U.S. Online Survey.” Archives of Sexual Behavior, 40(2): 429-39.</ref> * Cybersex allows for sexual exploration. For example, it can enable participants to act out fantasies which they would not act out (or perhaps would not even be realistically possible) in [[Real life (reality)|real life]] through [[roleplaying]] due to physical or social limitations<ref name="internetculture">{{Cite book | editor-last = Porter | editor-first = David | title = Internet Culture | publisher = Routledge | year = 1997 | isbn = 0-415-91684-4 | edition = paperback | last = Ito | first = Mizuko | authorlink = Mizuko Ito | contribution = Virtually Embodied: The Reality of Fantasy in a Multi-User Dungeon | pages = 95–96 | quote = She describes virtual sex as akin to an interactive romance novel. The metaphor is crucial. The fantasy "text" is paramount, the real bodies nonexistent. She explains: "It is how you describe yourself and how you act (on the Internet) that makes up the 'real you'.... real life persons' looks mean so little to me..." }}</ref>
* It takes less effort and fewer resources on the Internet than in real life to connect to a person like oneself or with whom a more meaningful relationship is possible.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==Criticism== Cybersex is often criticized because the partners frequently have little verifiable knowledge about each other.<ref name="hahngender">{{Cite book | last = Hahn | first = Harley | title = The Internet Complete Reference | edition = 2nd | publisher = Osborne McGraw-Hill | year = 1996 | isbn = 0-07-882138-X | page = 571 | quote = Finally, don't forget that the characters on a mud will not correspond exactly to the people in real life. In particular, what looks like a woman may really be a man. HINT: If you are a guy, and you go up to a female character on a mud and say, "Hi, wanna have sex?", and she says yes right away, chances are she is another guy playing a female role. }}</ref> For many the primary point of cybersex is the plausible simulation of sexual activity, and this knowledge of the other is not always desired, but this is also criticized as the emptying out of embodied relations.<ref>{{Cite journal | year= 1992 | last1= Carkeek | first1= Freya | last2= James | first2= Paul | authorlink2= Paul James (academic) | title= This Abstract Body | url= https://www.academia.edu/33643614/This_Abstract_Body_The_Self_the_Body_and_Identity_1992_ | journal= Arena | issue= 99–100 | pages= 66–85}}</ref>
In the words of Carkeek and James: {{cquote| Without continuing to draw off our historically ambivalent faith in embodied relations, techno-sex quickly becomes hollow, unsatisfying, no more erotic than collecting answers to what-are-your-measurements questions. And herein lies the rub, or so we will argue. By continuing to draw off that ambivalent faith, techno-sex and the many other practices of disembodying interaction contribute to a changing and increasingly abstracted dominant ontology of embodiment.<ref>{{Cite journal | year= 1992 | last1= Carkeek | first1= Freya | last2= James | first2= Paul | authorlink2= Paul James (academic) | title= This Abstract Body | url= https://www.academia.edu/33643614/This_Abstract_Body_The_Self_the_Body_and_Identity_1992_ | journal= Arena | issue= 99–100 | pages= 68}}</ref>}}
Privacy concerns are a difficulty with cybersex, since participants may log or record the interaction without the other's knowledge, and possibly disclose it to others or the public.<ref name="carton">{{Cite book | last = Carton | first = Sean | authorlink = Sean Carton | title = Internet Virtual Worlds Quick Tour | publisher = Ventana Press | year = 1995 | isbn = 1-56604-222-4 | page = 180 | quote = '''TinySex''' Simulated sexual activity done on a virtual world. Like the text equivalent of phone sex. It should be entered into with caution because you never know who's who online, and some people love enticing a person into an extended TinySex session and then posting a log of the activity to various newsgroups. }}</ref>
There is disagreement over whether cybersex is a form of [[infidelity]]. While it does not involve physical contact, critics claim that the powerful emotions involved can cause marital stress, especially when cybersex culminates in an [[Internet romance]]. In several known cases, Internet [[adultery]] became the grounds for which a couple divorced.<ref>{{cite web|last=Siemaszko |first=Corky |url=http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1996/02/02/1996-02-02_cybersplit__online_affair_sp.html |title=Cybersplit Online Affair Spurs Off-Line Divorce |work=New York Daily News |date=2006-02-02 |accessdate=2010-04-20 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090831040112/http://www.nydailynews.com/archives/news/1996/02/02/1996-02-02_cybersplit__online_affair_sp.html |archivedate=August 31, 2009 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web | last = Cable | first = Amanda | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/femail/article-1085915/Divorced-reality-All-accounts-Second-Life-love-triangle-saw-woman-separate-husband-having-cyber-affair.html | title = Divorced from reality: All three accounts of the Second Life love triangle that saw a woman separate from her husband for having a cyber-affair | work = Mail Online | date = 2008-11-14 | accessdate = 2010-04-20 }}</ref> Therapists report a growing number of patients addicted to this activity,<ref name="addict">{{Cite book | last = Godson | first = Suzi | title = The Sex Book | year = 2002 | publisher = Cassell Illustrated | isbn = 0-304-35991-2 | page = 258 }}</ref> a form of both [[Internet addiction]] and [[sexual addiction]], with the standard problems associated with addictive behavior.<ref name="autogenerated1"/>
==See also== *[[Cybersex addiction]] *[[Computer-mediated communication]] *[[Internet pornography]] *[[Sexting]] *[[Sextech]] *[[Teledildonics]]
==References== {{Reflist}}
==Further reading== * {{Cite journal | year= 1992 | last1= Carkeek | first1= Freya | last2= James | first2= Paul | authorlink2= Paul James (academic) | | title= This Abstract Body | url= https://www.academia.edu/33643614/This_Abstract_Body_The_Self_the_Body_and_Identity_1992_ | journal= Arena | issue= no. 99–100 | pages= 66–85}} * Deuel, N. R. (1996). "Our passionate response to virtual reality." in S. Herring (ed.), ''Computer-mediated communication: Linguistic, social and cross-cultural perspectives''. Amsterdam: John Benjamins Publishing Company, 129-146. {{ISBN|1-55619-803-5}}.
{{MUDs}} {{Sex}}
[[Category:Sexuality and computing]] [[Category:Sex industry]] [[Category:Internet culture]] [[Category:MUDs]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2015}} {{SSM}} A '''de facto union in [[Portugal]]''' (''união de facto'') is a form of [[civil union]] where a couple is legally recognized and granted similar rights as married couples, without having formally registered their relationship in a civil or religious marriage ceremony.
As with a [[common-law marriage]] (which is sometimes called "marriage in fact"), the act of the couple representing themselves to others as being married, and organizing their relation as if they were married, acts as the evidence for the legal recognition as a de facto union. However, unlike a common-law marriage, the status is not equivalent to a marriage: the legal rights and obligations of a couple in a de facto union are different from those of a married couple.
== History == {{Same-sex marriage map Europe|align=left|size=250px}}
De facto unions were first formally introduced for opposite-sex couples in ''Law no. 35/99'' of 1 July 1999, although some of the legal protections granted by the status already existed separately in various other laws, dating back to 1976. De facto unions were later extended to same-sex couples by ''Law no. 7/2001'' of 11 May 2001.<ref>{{pt icon}} [https://dre.pt/pdf1sdip/2001/05/109a00/27972798.pdf Law no. 7/2001, from 11 May] (specifically Article 1, no. 1).</ref> On the same day, a law on ''economia comum'' ("common economy") was also implemented, granting protection to two or more persons that live in common economy with most of the rights of the de facto union, except welfare benefits.
Since 5 June 2010, Portugal also recognizes [[Same-sex marriage in Portugal|same-sex marriage]], with de facto unions remaining as an alternative to couples (same-sex or opposite-sex) who do not wish to marry.
== Establishment and termination == There is no registration for the process. Rights can be claimed after a couple lives together for two years. An application of joint tax assessment can be made to prove the union but it is not required.
Portuguese de facto unions terminate upon the death or marriage of one of the partners, or upon request of one of the partners.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.angloinfo.com/lisbon/how-to/page/lisbon-family-marriage-partnerships-civil-partnerships|title=Civil Unions and Gay Marriage|website=Angloinfo Lisbon|publisher=[[Angloinfo]]|access-date=2016-06-16}}</ref>
== Rights == The law covers housing arrangements, [[civil servant]]s and work benefits, the option to choose a fiscal regime as married partners, and [[Welfare (financial aid)|welfare]] benefits. Since 1 March 2016, couples of any sex married or unmarried can adopt children together.<ref>[http://app.parlamento.pt/webutils/docs/doc.pdf?path=6148523063446f764c3246795a5868774d546f334e7a67774c336470626e526c654852766331396863484a76646d466b62334d764d6a41784e69394d587a4a664d6a41784e6935775a47593d&fich=L_2_2016.pdf&Inline=true Lei n.º 2/2016 de 29 de fevereiro]</ref>
Since December 2006, same-sex couples (and opposite-sex couples) living in a de facto union are also recognized in the same way as married couples for citizenship applications and when a public servant wants to extend healthcare protection to the partner.<ref>[http://www.om.acm.gov.pt/documents/58428/296070/b+naturalized_pt.pdf/9268c402-7b6e-4fce-b145-a543ebe716d8 INTI PROJECT: “BE NATURALIZED” REPORT ON NATURALISATION IN PORTUGAL]</ref>
Since 2007, a new [[Penal Code]] recognizes same-sex couples regarding domestic violence, the murder of a partner, refusal to testify in court against the partner and in all other situations where married couples are referred in the code.
In July 2009, the [[Assembly of the Republic (Portugal)|Portuguese Assembly]], with support of all the parties on the left, approved a bill to extend certain rights enjoyed by married couples, including inheritance rights, to couples in a de facto union.<ref>{{pt icon}} [http://www.tvi24.iol.pt/sociedade-nacional/deputados-parlamento-unioes-de-facto-tvi24-ultimas-noticias/1073492-4555.html AR altera lei das uniões de facto]</ref> On 24 August 2009, President [[Aníbal Cavaco Silva]] vetoed the bill.<ref>{{pt icon}} [http://tv1.rtp.pt/noticias/index.php?t=Veto-de-Belem-acentua-fractura-entre-esquerda-e-direita.rtp&article=273620&visual=3&layout=10&tm=9 Veto de Belém acentua fractura entre esquerda e direita]</ref>
On 9 July 2010, de facto union expansion law (that included inheritance rights, compensation and other benefits) passed the Portuguese Parliament and on 16 August 2010, President Cavaco Silva ratified the law.<ref>{{pt icon}} [http://aeiou.expresso.pt/cavaco-promulga-diploma-que-altera-unioes-de-facto=f599318 Cavaco promulga diploma que altera uniões de facto]</ref><ref>{{pt icon}} [http://www.parlamento.pt/ActividadeParlamentar/Paginas/DetalheIniciativa.aspx?BID=35327 Projecto de Lei 280/XI]</ref>
==See also== * [[Same-sex marriage in Portugal]] * [[LGBT rights in Portugal]] * [[Common-law marriage]] * [[Civil union]] * [[Domestic partnership]]
== References == {{reflist|30em}}
[[Category:Family in Portugal]] [[Category:Portuguese law]] [[Category:LGBT rights in Portugal]] [[Category:Recognition of same-sex relationships by country|Portugal]]

revision.text:
{{Multiple issues|{{Notability|Books|date=November 2009}} {{refimprove|date=November 2009}} {{original research|date=November 2009}} }} {{Infobox book | name = Diagnostics of Karma | image = Diagnostics of Karma - book cover.jpg | caption = Book cover of Diagnostics of Karma. All 12 books share the same design. | author = Sergei Lazarev | language = Russian | genre = [[Spirituality]], [[Philosophy]], [[Psychology]] | publisher = | release_date = 1993–2007 | isbn= }} '''Diagnostics of Karma''' ({{lang-ru|Диагностика Кармы}}) is a series of 12 books, written by '''Sergey Nikolayevich Lazarev''', a [[Russia]]n researcher and writer in [[bioenergetics]] and [[healing]]. The books were featured on Russian and [[Ukraine|Ukrainian]] TV via interviews with their author.<ref>[http://www.narod-vlast.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=189 "Интервью С.Н.Лазарева в программе «Вредные вопросы», г.Запорожье. 8.06.2003 г."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928020310/http://www.narod-vlast.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=189 |date=2007-09-28 }}, Narod-vlast.ru, July 23, 2006.</ref><ref>[http://www.narod-vlast.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=117 "Интервью С.Н.Лазарева в программе "Перша экспедицiя", г.Киев, 27.05.2005 г."] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070928015757/http://www.narod-vlast.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=117 |date=2007-09-28 }}, Narod-vlast.ru, June 28, 2006.</ref><ref>[http://www.narod-vlast.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=81 "Интервью С.Н.Лазарева в программе «По мнению», г.Самара. 28.02.2006 г."], Narod-vlast.ru, June 22, 2006. {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070615034421/http://www.narod-vlast.ru/index.php?option=com_content&task=view&id=81 |date=June 15, 2007 }}</ref>
== Content of books and their purpose ==
The twelve books embrace processes in the personal life of a human being, in politics, economics, ecology, weather, religion, science. All the processes are shown by the author as inseparably connected.
According to Lazarev's research, our deep emotions ''directly'' shape our health and fate. As the author himself puts it, the quintessence of all his research can be reduced to one phrase: "The meaning of life is love for God."<ref>Book two, p. 199. (1995 edition)</ref> The author has it that love (in the absolute sense, objectless and subjectless) engenders time, and, indirectly, space and matter;<ref>Book ten, p. 45</ref> that love is the absolute value.<ref>{{cite web|title=Book twelve|url=http://www.lazarev.ru/book/dk-12.html|language=ru|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080126080044/http://lazarev.ru/book/dk-12.html|archivedate=2008-01-26|df=}}</ref>
== Translations ==
Eight books have been translated to [[German language|German]]. Ten books have been translated to [[Polish language|Polish]] as of 2009-2015. All twelve books from the series have been translated and published in [[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]]. There are also a number of unauthorized [[Romanian language|Romanian]] translations, copies of which have found their way to the [[Toronto Public Library]]'s catalogue.<ref>[http://hip.tpl.toronto.on.ca/ipac20/ipac.jsp? session=11R3Q4886E569.1285286&profile=rs&source=~!rs&view=subscriptionsummary&uri=full=1100021~!9219570~!1&ri=6&aspect=subtab25&menu=search&ipp=20&spp=20&staffonly=&term=Lazarev,+Sergei%C3%8C%C2%86+Nikolaevich&index=AA&uindex=&aspect=subtab25&menu=search&ri=6 Toronto Public Library Catalogue], [[Toronto Public Library]]. {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20070706001712/http://hip.tpl.toronto.on.ca/ipac20/ipac.jsp |date=July 6, 2007 }}</ref>
In 2012 the first volume of Diagnostics of Karma ''The System of Field Self-regulation'' was translated to Spanish as ''[[Diagnosis del Karma]]''.{{fact|date=March 2015}} French translations of books two, three, four, and five are not yet published. {{fact|date=March 2015}}
== List of books' subtitles ==
Along with the common title of ''Diagnostics of Karma'', each book has its own subtitle.
===Russian volumes=== #The System of Field Self-regulation (1993, {{ISBN|5-900694-01-1}}) #Clear Karma (1995, {{ISBN|5-900694-02-X}}) #Love (1996, {{ISBN|5-900694-03-8}}) #Touching the Future (1997, {{ISBN|5-900694-04-6}}) #Answers to Questions (1998, {{ISBN|5-900694-04-6}}) #Steps to the Divine (1999, {{ISBN|5-900694-05-4}}) #Overcoming Sensual Happiness (2001, {{ISBN|5-900694-06-2}}) #Dialogue with the Readers (2003, {{ISBN|5-900694-08-9}}) #Survival Manual (2003, {{ISBN|5-900694-09-7}}) #Continuing the Dialogue (2005, {{ISBN|5-900694-10-0}}) #Concluding the Dialogue (2005, {{ISBN|5-900694-07-0}}) #Life As a Flicker of a Butterfly's Wings (2007, {{ISBN|978-5-900694-11-5}}) #First step to the future
===German volumes=== #Neue Sicht des Karma, Gesundheit und Schicksal als Ergebnis der eigenen Handlungen (2006, {{ISBN|3-9809005-0-9}}) #Antworten auf Fragen zum Karma und zur Veränderung des eigenen Schicksals (2004, {{ISBN|3-9809005-1-7}}) #Karmagesetze - Verbindung von Emotionen, Handlungen, Gedanken und vom Schicksal (2004, {{ISBN|3-9809005-2-5}}) #Wie unsere Emotionen das Schicksal gestalten (2004, {{ISBN|3-9809005-3-3}}) #Liebe (2007, {{ISBN|3-9809005-4-1}}) #Kontakt mit der Zukunft (2008, {{ISBN|3-9809005-5-X}})
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.lazarev.ru/ Official Russian website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20070415064938/http://www.lazarew.com/ Official German website] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110926093305/http://www.lazarev.es/ Official Spanish website] * [http://www.lazarev.bg/ Official Bulgarian website] *[http://alphann.ru/ Unofficial Russian forum] *[http://www.olazarenie.narod.ru/index_english.html Collected Christian criticisms on Diagnostics of Karma] *[http://apologetika.ru/pdfs/c097.pdf Critique by the Center for Apologetics Research]
{{DEFAULTSORT:Diagnostics Of Karma}} [[Category:New religious movements]]

[[File:Bunks in a Seven-Cent Lodging-House, Pell Street.jpeg|thumb|Bunks in a Seven Cent Lodging House, {{circa|1890}}]]
A '''flophouse''' ([[American English]]), '''doss-house''', or '''dosshouse''' ([[British English]]) is a place that offers very cheap [[lodging]], generally by providing only minimal services.<ref>[http://www.villagevoice.com/2005-02-22/nyc-life/the-last-of-the-mohicans/ The Last of the Mohicans—Searching for a place to flop on what was once skid row]</ref>
==Characteristics== A British "Doss-House" was used by those who needed a cheap alternative to staying on the street. Many would share a room which could be full of mats to sleep on, or a canvas sheet stretched between two horizontal beams creating a series of hammock like beds.
Occupants of flophouses generally share [[bathroom]] facilities and reside in very tight quarters. People who make use of these places are often [[transients]]. Quarters in flophouses are typically very small, and may resemble [[Cubicle desk|office cubicle]]s more than a regular room in a [[hotel]] or [[apartment building]].<ref name = "N.Y. Court says flophouses fall under rent stabilization laws">{{cite web | title = N.Y. Court says flophouses fall under rent stabilization laws | url = http://findarticles.com/p/articles/mi_m3601/is_n37_v40/ai_15195841 | accessdate = 2018-07-23 | deadurl = yes }}</ref> Some flophouses qualify as [[boarding house]]s, but only if they offer meals.
American flophouses date at least to the 19th century, but the term ''[[wikt:flophouse|flophouse]]'' itself is only attested from around the early 1900s, originating in [[hobo]] slang. In the past, flophouses were sometimes called ''lodging houses'' or ''workingmen's hotels'' and catered to [[hobo]]s and transient workers such as seasonal [[Rail transport|railroad]] and [[agriculture]] workers, or migrant [[lumberjacks]] who would travel west during the summer to work and then return to an eastern or [[midwestern]] city such as [[Chicago]] to stay in a flophouse during the winter. This is described in the [[1930 in literature|1930]] novel ''The Rambling Kid'' by [[Charles Ashleigh]] and the [[1976 in literature|1976]] book ''The Human Cougar'' by [[Lloyd Morain]]. Another theme in Morain's book is the [[gentrification]] which was then beginning and which has led cities to pressure flophouses to close.
[[File:Flophouse.jpg|thumb|A flophouse-style room]] Some city districts with flophouses in abundance became well known in their own right, such as the [[Bowery, Manhattan|Bowery]] in [[Manhattan]], [[New York City]]. Since the middle 20th century, reforms there have gradually made flophouses scarcer.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/01/14/magazine/the-big-city-save-the-flophouses.html|title=The Big City;Save the Flophouses|last=Tierney|first=John|access-date=2018-02-02|language=en}}</ref> The resulting gentrification and higher real-estate value has further eroded the ability of flophouses and inexpensive boarding-style hotels to make a profit.<ref>[http://ny.therealdeal.com/articles/from-flophouses-to-fancy-on-the-bowery From flophouses to fancy on the Bowery] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081017093516/http://ny.therealdeal.com/articles/from-flophouses-to-fancy-on-the-bowery |date=2008-10-17 }} from [http://ny.therealdeal.com/ The Real Deal Magazine] {{webarchive|url=http://webarchive.loc.gov/all/20131116125706/http://ny.therealdeal.com/ |date=2013-11-16 }}</ref>
== Cage homes in Hong Kong== [[Cage home]]s, described as "[[wire mesh]] cages resembling [[Hutch (animal cage)|rabbit hutches]] crammed into a dilapidated apartment", were built in [[Hong Kong]] in the 1950s for single working men from Mainland China.<ref name = "NBC">{{Cite episode | publisher = NBCNews.com | credits = Kelvin Chan (Director) | title = Poor in cages show dark side of Hong Kong boom | work = Economy Watch | agency = Associated Press | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | date = 2013-02-07 | url = http://www.nbcnews.com/business/economywatch/poor-cages-show-dark-side-hong-kong-boom-1B8287394 }}</ref> As of 2012, the number of impoverished residents in Hong Kong was estimated at 1.19 million, and cage homes, along with substandard housing such as cubicle apartments, were still serving a portion of this sector's housing needs.<ref name = "NBC"/> The combination of high rents and [[Economic inequality|income inequality]] has been given as one reason that cage homes persist.<ref name="Gargan">{{cite news|last=Gargan|first=Edward A.|title=In Rich Hong Kong, Cages as Homes for the Poor|work=The New York Times|page=6|date=14 July 1996|url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/07/14/world/in-rich-hong-kong-cages-as-homes-for-the-poor.html}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | last = Damien Gayle | title = Hong Kong's cage homes: Tens of thousands living in 6ft by 2ft rabbit hutches | work = Mail Online | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | date = 2012-01-11 | url = http://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-2084971/Hong-Kongs-cage-homes-Tens-thousands-living-6ft-2ft-rabbit-hutches.html }}</ref><ref>{{Cite news | title = Hong Kong cage home rents soar above luxury flat | work = Reuters | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | date = 2010-04-28 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/2010/04/28/us-hongkong-poverty-idUSTRE63R2KY20100428 }}</ref><ref>{{Cite episode | publisher = CNN.com | credits = Benjamin Gottlieb, Christie Hang (Director) | title = Hong Kong's poorest living in 'coffin homes' | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | date = 2011-07-26 | url = http://www.cnn.com/2011/WORLD/asiapcf/07/25/hongkong.coffin.homes/ }}</ref>
Michael Adorjan, a [[University of Hong Kong]] [[criminology]] professor, has noted that "The [[United Nations]] has called cage and cubicle homes an 'insult to human [[dignity]].'"<ref>{{Cite web | last = Michael Adorjan | title = Cage homes in Hong Kong: capitalism this Christmas | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | date = 2011-12-21 | url = http://www.crimetalk.org.uk/index.php?option=com_content&view=article&id=570%3Acage-homes-in-hong-kong&catid=38&Itemid=41 }}</ref>
== Cage hotels in the United States {{anchor|Cage hotel}}== '''Cage hotels''', a form of [[single room occupancy]], were common in [[Chicago]] at the turn of the 20th century; an estimated 40,000 to 60,000 people lived in them during the winter.
{{quote|These were lofts or other large, open buildings that were subdivided into tiny [[cubicle]]s using boards or sheets of [[Corrugated galvanised iron|corrugated iron]]. Since these walls were always one to three feet short of the floor or ceiling, the open space was sealed off with [[chicken wire]], hence the name “cage hotels."<ref>{{Cite encyclopedia | title = Single Room Occupancy Hotels | encyclopedia = [[Encyclopedia of Chicago]] | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | url = http://www.encyclopedia.chicagohistory.org/pages/613.html }}</ref>}}
A 1958 survey by [[Christopher Jencks]] found that homeless men preferred cage hotels over [[Homeless shelter|shelters]] for reasons of privacy and security.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Christopher Jencks | title = Housing the Homeless | work = [[The New York Review of Books]] | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | url = http://www.nybooks.com/articles/archives/1994/may/12/housing-the-homeless/ }}</ref>
A similar preference for cage hotels over shelters was reported in turn of the century [[New York City]], where single working men ranked their housing preference in the following order:
{{quote|They preferred lodging and [[boarding house]]s to cages, cages to [[Dormitory|dormitories]], dormitories to flops, and flops to the city’s shelters. Men could act on these preferences by moving as their incomes increased.<ref>{{Cite news |issue = Summer |last = Filer |first = Randall K |authorlink = Randall K. Filer |title = Opening the Door to Low-Cost Housing |work = [[City Journal (New York)|City Journal]] |accessdate = 2013-02-13 |date = 1992 |url = http://www.city-journal.org/article01.php?aid=1529 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20120620080305/http://www.city-journal.org/article01.php?aid=1529 |archivedate = 2012-06-20 |df = }}</ref>}}
"Regulatory efforts to combat low-cost 'cage hotels,' ... [has been] a driver of the expansion of the [[Homelessness in the United States|homeless population in US cities]]", according to Jencks.<ref>{{Cite news | last = Reihan Salam | title = The Agenda: Stephen Smith on the Missing Driverless Trains | work = [[National Review|National Review Online]] | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | url = http://www.nationalreview.com/agenda/309617/stephen-smith-missing-driverless-trains-reihan-salam?toggle=y }}</ref>
==See also== * [[Capsule hotel]] * [[Common lodging-house]] * [[Hostel]] * [[Punk house]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==Further reading== {{wiktionary}} *{{Cite book | publisher = M. Jones Co. | last = Jesse Walter Dees | title = Flophouse; an authentic undercover study of flophouses, cage hotels, including missions, shelters and institutions serving unattached (homeless) men. A sociological study that includes English origins of mass relief, samples of American mass relief and a modern investigation of public and private policies in Chicago. | location = Francestown, New Hampshire | accessdate = 2013-02-13 | date = 1948 | url = http://www.worldcat.org/title/flophouse-an-authentic-undercover-study-of-flophouses-cage-hotels-including-missions-shelters-and-institutions-serving-unattached-homeless-men-a-sociological-study-that-includes-english-origins-of-mass-relief-samples-of-american-mass-relief-and-a-modern-investigation-of-public-and-private-policies-in-chicago/oclc/494608&referer=brief_results }}
[[Category:Homelessness]] [[Category:Hotel types]] [[Category:Urban decay]]

revision.text:
{{Generations Sidebar}}
The '''G.I. Generation''' (also known as the '''WWII Generation''' or '''[[The Greatest Generation]]''' in the United States or the '''Federation Generation''' in [[Australia]]) is the demographic cohort following the [[Lost Generation]]. There are no precise dates for when this cohort starts or ends; demographers and researchers typically use the early 1900s as starting birth years and ending birth years in the mid-1920s.
==Definition== This generation experienced much of their youth during rapid [[technological innovation]] (radio, telephone) amidst growing levels of worldwide [[income inequality]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://eml.berkeley.edu//~saez/saez-UStopincomes-2012.pdf |title=Striking it Richer |website=eml.berkeley.edu |format=PDF}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2013/12/05/u-s-income-inequality-on-rise-for-decades-is-now-highest-since-1928/|title=U.S. income inequality, on rise for decades, is now highest since 1928|date=5 December 2013|publisher=}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pewresearch.org/fact-tank/2014/01/07/5-facts-about-economic-inequality/|title=5 facts about economic inequality|date=7 January 2014|publisher=}}</ref> and a soaring economy.<ref>{{cite journal|url=http://www.pnas.org/content/106/41/17290|title=Life and death during the Great Depression|first1=José A. Tapia|last1=Granados|first2=Ana V. Diez|last2=Roux|date=13 October 2009|publisher=|journal=Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences|volume=106|issue=41|pages=17290–17295|via=www.pnas.org|doi=10.1073/pnas.0904491106|pmid=19805076}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.shmoop.com/1920s/economy.html|title=Economy in The 1920s|website=www.shmoop.com}}</ref><ref>George H. Soule, Prosperity Decade: From War to Depression: 1917–1929 (1947)</ref> After the [[Stock Market Crash of 1929|Stock Market crashed]], this generation experienced profound economic and social turmoil, which eventually culminated in [[World War II]].
Demographers [[Strauss–Howe generational theory|William Stauss and Neil Howe]] coined the term "G.I. Generation" in their 1991 book ''Generations: The History of America's Future''<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FTGY-uoCCCoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=generations#v=onepage&q=generations&f=false |title=Generations: The History of America's Future, 1584 to 2069 |first=William|last=Strauss|first2=Neil|last2=Howe|publisher=Harper Perennial |year=1991|isbn=9780688119126 }} p. 335</ref> and use 1901–1924 as birth years.<ref name = "Howe">{{cite news|last1=Howe|first1=Neil|title=The G.I. Generation and the "Triumph of the Squares"|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/neilhowe/2014/07/30/the-g-i-generation-and-the-triumph-of-the-squares-part-2-of-7/#14f6fc301a1d|accessdate=26 November 2016|publisher=Forbes|date=30 July 2014}}</ref> The initials [[G.I. (military)|"G.I."]] of "G.I. Generation" is military terminology referring to "Government Issue" or "General Issue". This cohort is also referred to as the "World War II Generation".<ref>{{cite news|title=The Greatest Generation|url=http://www.investopedia.com/terms/t/the_greatest_generation.asp|accessdate=26 November 2016|publisher=Investopia}}</ref>
McCrindle Research expanded on Howe's work and uses the term ''Federation Generation'' to describe [[Australians|Australian]] members of this cohort, born between 1901–1924, "a time of peace when Australia finally secured nationhood" who came of age during The [[Great Depression]] and WWII and experienced post-war prosperity in midlife.<ref>[http://mccrindle.com.au/resources/whitepapers/McCrindle-Research_ABC-01_Generations-Defined_Mark-McCrindle.pdf Generations Defined]. Mark McCrindle {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160616232732/http://mccrindle.com.au/resources/whitepapers/McCrindle-Research_ABC-01_Generations-Defined_Mark-McCrindle.pdf |date=2016-06-16 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news|last1=McCrindle|first1=Mark|title=The ABC of XYZ Understanding the Global Generations|url=http://www.saspa.com.au/wp-content/uploads/2016/02/The-ABC-of-XYZ_Chapter-1.pdf|accessdate=25 May 2018|publisher=McCrindle Research}}</ref>
[[Pew Research Center]] defines this cohort as being born from 1901 to 1927.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.people-press.org/2016/12/15/americans-name-the-10-most-significant-historic-events-of-their-lifetimes/|title=Americans Name the 10 Most Significant Historic Events of Their Lifetimes|date=15 December 2016|publisher=People Press}}</ref>
The term ''[[The Greatest Generation]]'', which is a term sometimes used to refer to the US members of this cohort, comes from the title of 1998 book by American journalist [[Tom Brokaw]]. In the book, Brokaw profiled American members of this generation who came of age during the Great Depression and went on to fight in [[World War II]], as well as those who contributed to the war effort on the home front. Brokaw wrote that these men and women fought not for fame or recognition, but because it was the "right thing to do."<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=rQagD17IFS4C&q=the+greatest+generation&dq=the+greatest+generation&cd=1 |title=The greatest generation - Tom Brokaw - Google Boeken |publisher=Books.google.com |date= |accessdate=2013-12-16|isbn=9780375502026 |year=1998 }}</ref>
==Notable members== Sample members include [[Walt Disney]], [[Charles Lindberg]], [[John Steinbeck]]. Notable actors [[Bob Hope]], [[Katharine Hepburn]], [[Sidney Poitier]] and [[John Wayne]]. U.S. presidents were [[Lyndon B. Johnson]], [[Ronald Reagan]], [[Richard Nixon]], [[Gerald Ford]], [[John F. Kennedy]], [[Jimmy Carter]] and [[George H. W. Bush]]. The American automobile executive best known for making the development of Ford Mustang and Pinto cars [[Lee Iacocca]] and theoretical physicist and professor of physics [[Robert Oppenheimer]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FTGY-uoCCCoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=generations#v=onepage&q=generations&f=false |title=Generations: The History of America's Future, 1584 to 2069 |first=William|last=Strauss|first2=Neil|last2=Howe|publisher=Harper Perennial |year=1991|isbn=978-0688119126 }} p. 262</ref>
Prominent international peers include [[George Orwell]], [[Leonid Brezhnev]], [[Willy Brandt]] and [[Ferdinand Marcos]].<ref>{{cite book|url=https://books.google.com/?id=FTGY-uoCCCoC&printsec=frontcover&dq=generations#v=onepage&q=generations&f=false |title=Generations: The History of America's Future, 1584 to 2069 |first=William|last=Strauss|first2=Neil|last2=Howe|publisher=Harper Perennial |year=1991|isbn=978-0688119126 }} p. 262</ref>
==See also== {{Portal|World War II|1910s|1920s}}
* [[Generation gap]] * [[Greatest Generation]] * [[List of generations]]
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Cultural gens}} {{DEFAULTSORT:G.I. Generation}} [[Category:20th century]] [[Category:Aftermath of World War II in the United States]] [[Category:American people of World War II]] [[Category:Cultural generations]] [[Category:Cultural history of World War II]] [[Category:People of World War II]] [[Category:Words coined in the 1990s]]
